content.description: A steeper start leads to a crack, then to an easy slab.
content.protection: Unless top-roping, the overhanging moves at the start require precise placements of small nuts to keep it safe.  Gear to 3 inches, with emphasis on smaller stoppers & offset nuts.  Rappel from bolts.
content.location: In about the middle of the feature, a smoothish wall that stands out just a bit from the rock to its left.  The Jack is the left-hand of the two obvious crack routes on this part of the wall.

content.description: Start on the face right under the tree (avoiding the crack on the left to make it more challenging).  Crux comes in the last third, on a nice pumpy slab with some fun moves.
content.protection: TR from the bolts at the top (when you're standing up top, the bolts are in front of the last tree on the right).  Bring long/multiple slings to cut down on rope drag over the edge.  Don't know if this could be done as a trad route.
content.location: Furthest wall to the left, starting right under the tree.

content.description: The guidebook list this route as basically starting up "The Apex" but to maximize decent climbing I tackled the route via the "Sidewalk" start, then as you pull onto the lower angle slab finish of sidewalk climb straight up the left side of the arête for another 20 ft of thin face holds and using the arête itself. Soon you will be pulling the smooth block holds the guide describes at the finish.
content.protection: Could ledge if an R/X rating using the "sidewalk" start. Best TR'd, double bolt anchors on top.
content.location: Summit Wall group, Climbing the arete between Sidewalk and Apex

content.description: Climb the broken rock at the base, and choose either the left or right side of the V crack. After the two cracks merge, continue up the short crack/chimney to an old stump. Walk across the top ledge to a set of bolts.
content.protection: Pro to 2", bolted anchor with rap rings. Maybe a larger cam or two (BD 5 or 6).
content.location: Near the center of the large downed log at the base of the climb

content.description: From below the left crack of The Apex, ascend to the base of a slab slanting up to the left. At the top of the slab, from a small ledge, continue up and to the left.
content.location: Left of The Apex. Starts near (just right of, facing the wall) the leftmost large tree at the base of the wall.

content.description: Really fun for the grade! Balancey moves and jugs the whole way up. A couple of bushes growing in the crack probably increasing the challenge of placing gear. A fun warmup on TR but bring some cordelette to extend the anchor over a lip to reduce rope drag.
content.location: Start to the left of the lefmost tree at the base of the wall. Work to the left up a ramp, then straight up over a bulge.

content.description: Starts about 5' right of Jack of Diamonds.  Some boulder moves to get off the ground, tough feet.  Gain the face and use small holds to get up.  Staying more left goes @ 5.9 while the middle of the face goes @ 5.10a
content.protection: Two sets of anchors to choose from to setup the TR. One older set of chains (climbers left) and a set of bomber hangers. Can access both from the top if you don't want to lead Jack or King.
content.location: Right side of Summit wall.  Right between Jack of Diamonds and King of Diamonds.

content.description: An easy beginning leads to a short hand crack with an airy, exposed feel, then more easy ground to anchors.
content.protection: Minimal protection on the lower portion beneath the corner. Gear to 2" for the middle crack. Bolted anchors on top, good for top roping.
content.location: Wander up easier & lower-angled ground beneath the feature & climb the short crack in the left-facing corner, to the left of the overhanging "nose."

content.description: Climb the Joker until you are level with the bottom of the nose.  Traverse left to side of the nose, step across (crux) and ascend the open book.  Easier terrain takes you past multiple sets of bolted anchors at the cliff top.  Steep and exposed with decent pro on lead.
content.location: first route immediately right of the Nose feature

content.description: Start directly under the nose. Wander up to the face.  Use small holds up to the underclings on the bottom of the nose. Grab the Flake and throw a left heel hook to pull over the nose for the crux. Continue up the "bridge" of the nose to the anchors.
content.protection:
Set of Chains. Accessible from the top. Shares anchor with Open Book and The Nose.

BETA: Make sure when trying to pull the nose that your rope runs down the nose directly off the tip or it could hamper you attempts to pull the crux.
content.location: Prominent overhanging feature in the middle of Summit Wall.  Right of the 5.0 Gully

content.description: Start just left of the tree.  Couple boulder moves to get off the ground to good holds.  Move right into the crack and follow for about 10 feet.  Make a small traverse left and up to gain easier ground. Run it out to the anchors.
content.location: Right side of Summit Wall. Just left of a tree.  Can step off the root to start the route.

content.description: Good lead for beginner trad climbers.  Climb up easy rock to a large notch. Continue up a crack of fractured rock into the an open V book.  Gain the top and walk to the anchors.
content.protection: Pro to 2.5", Bolted anchor on top (no chains).Second set of anchors further back but need (very) long runners to extend them to reduce rope drag.
content.location: Right of Center of Summit Wall.  Right of the Nose.
